raw_text:
Little Britain two top comic list
 
 Little Britain stars Matt Lucas and David Walliams have been named the most powerful people in TV comedy, in a poll by listings magazine Radio Times.
 
 The duo kept Phoenix Nights creator Peter Kay at number two and The Office star Ricky Gervais in third place. A Radio Times panel compiled the list, taking the comedians' critical acclaim and financial success into account. Newcomers to the annual list included Nighty Night star Julia Davis at seven and Black Books' Tamsin Greig at 19.
 
 Lucas and Walliams won numerous awards for Little Britain in 2004, including National Television, Royal Television Society and British Comedy awards. More than 1.8 million people watched the first episode of the latest series of Little Britain on BBC Three in October, giving the digital channel its highest rating ever.
 
 They topped the Radio Times list after rising from 10th position last year. Other big risers over the past year included presenting duo Ant and Dec at five, up from 13 in 2004, Stephen Fry rising nine places to 15 and BBC Three controller Stuart Murphy, who moves to number 18 from 32 last year. Last year's winner, chat show host Graham Norton, fell to number 16 following relatively few television appearances in 2004. Production companies also featured in the top 50, including Steve Coogan's Baby Cow, which created Nighty Night among others, Hat Trick - behind The Kumars at Number 42 - and The Vicar of Dibley production company Tiger Aspect.

Others on list include Peter Kay, Ricky Gervais, Julia Davis, Tamsin Greig, Ant & Dec, Stephen Fry, Stuart Murphy, Steve Coogan's Baby Cow, Hat Trick, and The Vicar of Dibley producer Tiger Aspect. Lucas and Walliams rose to second after winning multiple awards for Little Britain in 2004 and achieving highest BBC Three rating with series premiere.

The duo kept Phoenix Nights creator Peter Kay at number two and The Office star Ricky Gervais in third place, while a new panel compiled the list taking into account the comedians' critical acclaim and financial success. Newcomers to the annual list included Nighty Night star Julia Davis at seven and Black Books' Tamsin Greig at 19.

The list was compiled by Radio Times, which has been publishing lists of the most powerful people in TV comedy since 2004. The list takes into account the comedians' critical acclaim and financial success as well as their influence on the industry. Newcomers to the list included presenter duo Ant and Dec at number one, followed by Stephen Fry rising nine places to number 15 from 32 last year.

The list also features other big risers over the past year, including presenter duo Ant and Dec at number 18 from 32 last year, Stuart Murphy moving up three places to number 42 from 32 last year, and BBC Three controller Steve Coogan who moves up two places to number 16 from 32 last year.

Production companies also featured in the top 50, including Steve Coogan's Baby Cow, which created Nighty Night among others, Hat Trick behind The Vicar of Dibley production company Tiger Aspect and The Kumars at Number 42 - behind The Vicar of Dibley production company Tiger Aspect.

tinyllama:1.1b:
Top Comedy Stars in UK: A List from Radio Times Poll

Littl Britain stars Matt Lucas and David Walliams, also known as the top duo in TV comedy for a decade now, are the most powerful people in the industry according to a listing compiled by British Listings magazine Radio Times. The two received 40.9% of the poll's 10,000 votes, taking them from seventh place in 2003 to second place in 2005. The duo also climbed nine places to fifth place last year, following numerous appearances on TV shows such as Little Britain, The Office, and Black Books. Other rising stars included Ant & Dec at five and Stephen Frary's show BBC Three Controller rising nine places from number 32 in 2004. Production companies also made it into the top 50, with production companies like Steve Coogan's Baby Cow and The Vicar of Dibley being ranked behind The Kuarms at number 42.
